content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <metadata>  <idinfo>   <citation>    <citeinfo>     <pubdate>Unknown</pubdate>     <title>StreamNet Query System: Smolt Density Model</title>     <ftname Sync="TRUE">Query system output</ftname><pubinfo><pubplace>Portland, Oregon</pubplace><publish>StreamNet Project, Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission</publish></pubinfo><onlink>http://query.streamnet.org/Request.cfm?cmd=BuildCriteria&NewQuery=BuildCriteria&Required=Run&DataCategory=21</onlink><onlink>http://www.streamnet.org/</onlink><origin>Northwest Power Planning Council</origin><pubtime>Unknown</pubtime><onlink>http://www.streamnet.org/onlinehelp/user_guide_03.html</onlink></citeinfo>   </citation>   <descript>    <abstract>In response to a need for Columbia Basin wide evaluation of anadromous production potential during the Northwest Power Planning Council's Subbasin Planning Process, two work groups, the System Planning Group (SPG) and the Monitoring and Evaluation Group (MEG) developed the Smolt Density Model (SDM). The primary output of this model was an estimate of smolt carrying capacity by subbasin and stock which was used in the Council's System Planning Model (SPM). The SPM was a life cycle model used to predict effects on salmon and steelhead due to various strategies proposed by the planners. This model also provided an updated distribution dataset, along with a subjective habitat rating by species/run. This dataset contains output from the SDM (described above) and associated stream, taxonomic, life history, and physical habitat information.    This data category is available through StreamNet's online query system, which allows users to explore and filter the StreamNet database and download selected results. For help in using the StreamNet query system, please consult the user guide, available at http://www.streamnet.org/onlinehelp/user_guide_03.html</abstract>    <langdata>English</langdata><supplinf>Taxa: Chinook salmon (Oncorhynchus tshawytscha) Coho salmon (Oncorhynchus kisutch) steelhead (Oncorhynchus mykiss)  StreamNet is a cooperative information management and dissemination project focused on fisheries and aquatic related data in the Columbia River basin and the Pacific Northwest. The project provides a variety of data related to fish resources and maintains the 1:100,000 scale hydrography layer for the Pacific Northwest. Information is available through an on-line database query, interactive maps, direct data download or by custom request.    StreamNet receives funding from the Bonneville Power Administration (BPA Project No.: 198810804) and is authorized under the Fish and Wildlife Program of the Northwest Power and Conservation Council.  Other organizations provide funding for select project components.  Participating agencies contribute significant in-kind services and include: the Oregon Dept. of Fish and Wildlife (ODFW), Washington Dept. of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW), Idaho Dept. of Fish and Game (IDFG), Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks (MFWP), U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS), and the Columbia River Inter-Tribal Fisheries Commission (CRITFC).</supplinf></descript>   <timeperd> <overview><dsoverv>In response to a need for Columbia Basin wide evaluation of anadromous production potential during the Northwest Power Planning Council's Subbasin Planning Process, two work groups, the System Planning Group (SPG) and the Monitoring and Evaluation Group (MEG) developed the Smolt Density Model (SDM). The primary output of this model was an estimate of smolt carrying capacity by subbasin and stock which was used in the Council's System Planning Model (SPM). The SPM was a life cycle model used to predict effects on salmon and steelhead due to various strategies proposed by the planners. This model also provided an updated distribution dataset, along with a subjective habitat rating by species/run.  </dsoverv><eaover>This dataset contains output from the Smolt Density Model (SDM) and associated stream, taxonomic, life history, and physical habitat information.</eaover></overview><detailed><attr><attrlabl>Subbasin</attrlabl><attrdef>Area defined by the Northwest Power Planning Council within the Columbia River Basin, and StreamNet staff in other areas</attrdef><attrdefs>StreamNet Project, Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission</attrdefs></attr><attr><attrlabl>River Reach Number</attrlabl><attrdef>Primary key for table Reach: 1:250,000 scale EPA River Reach number</attrdef><attrvai/><attrdefs>StreamNet Project, Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission</attrdefs></attr><attr><attrlabl>Stream Name</attrlabl><attrdef>Name of the stream for which data within a record are relevant</attrdef><attrvai/><attrdefs>StreamNet Project, Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission</attrdefs></attr><attr><attrlabl>Tributary Name</attrlabl><attrdef>Name of the water body to which the specified stream is a tributary</attrdef><attrdefs>StreamNet Project, Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission</attrdefs></attr><attr><attrlabl>From</attrlabl><attrdef>Name of the complementary reach that defines the lower boundary of the immediate reach</attrdef><attrdefs>StreamNet Project, Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission</attrdefs></attr><attr><attrlabl>To</attrlabl><attrdef>Name of the reach(s) that defines the upper boundary of the immediate reach, if different from the immediate reach name.</attrdef><attrdefs>StreamNet Project, Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission</attrdefs></attr><attr><attrlabl>Sequence Number</attrlabl><attrdefs>StreamNet Project, Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission</attrdefs><attrdef>Hydrologic sequence number</attrdef></attr><attr><attrdomv/><attrlabl>Species</attrlabl><attrdef>Fish species (common name - Chinook, steelhead, etc.)</attrdef><attrdefs>StreamNet Project, Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission</attrdefs></attr><attr><attrdomv/><attrlabl>Run</attrlabl><attrdef>Fish run</attrdef><attrdefs>StreamNet Project, Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission</attrdefs></attr><attr><attrlabl>Present</attrlabl><attrdef>Lineal percentage of the reach occupied by the species from the base of the reach upstream</attrdef><attrdefs>StreamNet Project, Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission</attrdefs></attr><attr><attrlabl>Length Miles</attrlabl><attrdef>Length of the specified reach in miles</attrdef><attrdefs>StreamNet Project, Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission</attrdefs></attr><attr><attrlabl>Width Feet</attrlabl><attrdef>Estimate of the mean summer low flow width of the reach in feet</attrdef><attrdefs>StreamNet Project, Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission</attrdefs></attr><attr><attrdomv/><attrlabl>Use Type</attrlabl><attrdef>Describes how the specified reach is utilized by particular fish species </attrdef><attrdefs>StreamNet Project, Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission</attrdefs></attr><attr><attrdomv/><attrlabl>Habitat Quality</attrlabl><attrdef>Subjective estimate of habitat quality for the given species/run for the reach, based on comparisons of the present fish producing potential of habitat within the subbasin that contains the reach. Excellent habitat was described as that which would support the highest productivity for a species within the subbasin. Poor was the classification for habitat which would support the lowest level of productivity of some reasonable number of fish. Good and Fair classifications were used to describe habitat which was intermediate relative to the other two categories.</attrdef><attrdefs>StreamNet Project, Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission</attrdefs></attr><attr><attrlabl>Smolt Capacity</attrlabl><attrdef>Estimate of the theoretical smolt carrying capacity of a production area at zero density. This value was used as the asymptote for the density dependent Beverton-Holt production function used in the Council's System Planning life cycle model</attrdef><attrdefs>StreamNet Project, Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission</attrdefs></attr><enttyp><enttypl>Smolt Density Model</enttypl><enttypd>Dataset downloaded from http://www.streamnet.org</enttypd></enttyp></detailed></eainfo>
